<Summary source="https://lamag.com/news-and-politics/armenian-officials-press-diplomatic-agenda-in-los-angeles-amid-regional-tensions/">
## Summary

**Disclaimer:** This article is entirely unrelated to the Lamag by-election in Sabah, Malaysia. "LAmag" here refers to a Los Angeles-based publication, and the article covers Armenian diplomatic outreach to the Armenian-American community in Southern California. It contains **no information relevant** to the Lamag by-election question.

---

### Article Content (for completeness):

The article covers a visit by senior Armenian government officials — including Lilit Makunts (chief adviser to PM Nikol Pashinyan) and Arayik Harutyunyan (Armenia's Chief of Staff) — to Los Angeles to engage the Armenian-American diaspora on foreign policy matters. Key topics include:

- **U.S.–Armenia relations**, highlighted by a recent visit to Yerevan by VP JD Vance (described as the highest-level U.S. visit to Armenia in modern history)
- **Nuclear energy cooperation** and a joint statement signed by Pashinyan and Vance, criticized by journalist Harut Sassounian as financially unviable and technologically unproven
- **The TRIPP corridor** (Trump Route for International Peace and Prosperity), a transit project raising sovereignty concerns
- **Armenia's June 7 parliamentary elections** and concerns about disinformation campaigns
- **Ongoing Nagorno-Karabakh humanitarian issues**, including detainees and border negotiations

**This article provides no relevant information for forecasting the Lamag (Sabah) by-election question.**
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Sabah_state_election">
## Summary: 2025 Sabah State Election

**Overview:**
The 17th Sabah state election was held on **29 November 2025**, contesting all 73 seats. The result was a **hung assembly**, with incumbent Chief Minister Hajiji Noor's **Gabungan Rakyat Sabah (GRS)** winning the most seats (29) but falling short of a majority.

**Key Coalitions/Parties:**
- **GRS** (led by Hajiji Noor) allied with **Pakatan Harapan (PH)** via electoral pact
- **WARISAN** (led by Shafie Apdal) as main opposition
- **Perikatan Nasional (PN)** contested all 73 seats for the first time under its own banner
- Several parties contested independently: **STAR, SAPP, UPKO, KDM, BN, MCA**

**Notable Pre-Election Developments:**
- STAR and SAPP left GRS in October 2025; UPKO exited PH in November 2025
- KDM's president Peter Anthony was jailed after losing a court appeal (March 2025), with his daughter appointed acting president
- Key campaign issues included **Sabah autonomy/"Sabah for Sabahans" sentiment**, a **mining license corruption scandal** involving secret recordings by businessman Albert Tei, and revenue-sharing disputes

**Relevance to Lamag By-Election Question:**
The article does not contain any specific information about the **Lamag constituency** or a scheduled **January 24, 2026 by-election**, though the hung assembly result from the November 2025 election could be contextually relevant to understanding the political environment in which such a by-election would occur.

*Disclaimer: The article does not directly address the Lamag by-election or any electoral annulments/legal challenges relevant to the forecasting question.*
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.bernama.com/en/news.php?id=2514374">
## Summary: Kinabatangan & Lamag By-Election Logistics (Bernama, January 20, 2026)

### Key Facts & Statistics

- **Results expected by approximately 10 PM** on January 24, 2026, for both the Kinabatangan parliamentary and Lamag state by-elections
- **Lamag seat has 13,899 registered electors**; Kinabatangan constituency (which includes Lamag) has 48,722 total registered voters
- **36 ordinary polling centres** comprising **117 polling streams** will be used
- **8 polling centres** require helicopter services; **1 polling centre** (SK Tundun Bohangin) requires boat transport
- Closing time at interior polling centres has been moved forward from **3 PM to 2 PM** to mitigate weather-related delays
- EC is targeting **voter turnout above 65%** for both by-elections
- Early voting: 189 of 196 police personnel voted in person; 7 voted by post
- **Starlink facilities** deployed to ensure internet connectivity during vote tallying

### Electoral Context
- **Lamag** is a straight fight between **Mohd Ismail Ayob (BN)** and **Mazliwati Abdul Malek (Warisan)**
- By-elections triggered by the **death of incumbent Datuk Seri Bung Moktar Radin** on December 5, 2025

### Complaints/Incidents
- EC chairman confirmed **one complaint received** on January 20, though details were pending; described the overall process as "orderly, smooth and without any serious incidents"
</Summary>

Query: Will the official result of the Lamag by-election (Sabah), scheduled for January 24, 2026, be overturned before May 1, 2026?
Here are the relevant news articles:

**24 Groups Urge Anwar to Protect Indigenous Customary Land Rights Amid Escalating Dispossession Cases**
Twenty-four civil society organizations in Malaysia have issued a joint statement urging Prime Minister Dato' Seri Anwar Ibrahim to fulfill his reform promises by fully protecting indigenous customary land rights, following a series of incidents across multiple states. In Terengganu, 51 residents from 14 families were displaced from their ancestral forest area in Long Unu Bukit Bak in January to make way for a religious education institution, despite the land being their traditional territory before relocation to Sungai Burung. In Pahang, 21 indigenous people were detained on February 9 after entering land claimed by a development company; community representatives argue they acted without 'free, prior, and informed consent' to defend their ancestral land. In Selangor, the Pulau Kali indigenous craft center raised concerns on February 11 about the approval of the West Port expansion project without community consent, with RimbaWatch’s preliminary findings indicating a proposed oil terminal near Kampung Sungai Kular could cause severe pollution and habitat destruction. On February 12, roadblocks set up by communities in Kelantan’s Chenderoh region to protest a 2,000-hectare resort and agricultural development project were dismantled by police and forestry officials, despite a memorandum submitted in August 2024 opposing the plan due to threats to customary land and ecology. The organizations stress that Anwar’s 2023 Pakatan Harapan election pledge to protect indigenous land rights has not been upheld, despite prior national surveys and court rulings. They call on the government to honor its obligations under the 2007 UN Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples and implement recommendations from SUHAKAM’s national survey on indigenous land rights.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 21, 2026 05:57 AM
Source:[星洲日报](https://www.sinchew.com.my/news/20260221/nation/7285547)

**DAP's next move under scrutiny**
The Democratic Action Party (DAP) is under political scrutiny as its upcoming special congress on July 12, 2026, is seen as a pivotal moment for its future alignment within Pakatan Harapan. While PKR’s R. Yuneswaran and Pasir Gudang MP Hassan Abdul Karim emphasize unity and mutual respect, stressing that DAP’s 40 parliamentary seats are critical to Prime Minister Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim’s administration—such a withdrawal would mathematically collapse the government—Amanah’s Muhammad Faiz Fadzil and Khalid Samad urge DAP to remain in government to preserve coalition strength and policy influence. Universiti Malaya analyst Professor Datuk Dr Awang Azman Awang Pawi warns that if DAP leaders resign from government, the administration’s majority could be jeopardized, risking political instability. Ilham Centre CEO Hisommudin Bakar interprets the congress as a response to voter dissatisfaction revealed in the recent Sabah election, particularly among Chinese urban voters, signaling a need to prevent a broader rejection in Peninsular Malaysia. He cautions that failing to adopt more responsive policies may lead to stronger voter backlash in the 16th General Election (GE16). DAP secretary-general Anthony Loke confirmed the congress would allow delegates to decide whether leaders should relinquish all government posts, though the party will continue supporting Anwar’s government until the end of the current term. The congress aims to secure a mandate from delegates on DAP’s strategic direction ahead of GE16.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 20, 2026 11:25 PM
Source:[The Star ](https://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2026/02/21/daps-next-move-under-scrutiny)

**Melaka assembly may dissolve in April, state poll expected in June**
The Melaka state legislative assembly may be dissolved during its April sitting, potentially leading to a state election in early June, according to multiple state political party leaders. Melaka PKR strategy director Mohd Radzmin Roslan confirmed the party is preparing for a possible three-cornered contest, particularly if Barisan Nasional does not cooperate with Pakatan Harapan, and is coordinating with DAP and Amanah. The state poll could occur before the PKR national congress scheduled for June 25–28 in Melaka. Melaka DAP’s Low Chee Leong stated that while speculation about an April dissolution exists, it remains unconfirmed and awaits the next assembly sitting. Melaka Gerakan chief Datuk Seri Michael Gan Peng Lam confirmed growing talk of dissolution in mid-April to enable a June election, noting preparations are underway with Perikatan Nasional partners. He emphasized that the recent resignation of Datuk Mas Ermieyati Samsudin and 39 committee members from Masjid Tanah Bersatu is an internal party matter and will not affect state-level election preparations. Political observer Michael Ching suggested the timing might be strategic, possibly aligning with a Johor state election and a concurrent parliamentary dissolution. He noted Barisan Nasional is expected to contest under its own banner, citing strong grassroots support through programs like Wakil Rakyat Untuk Rakyat (WRUR) and state fiscal development. Umno president Datuk Seri Dr Ahmad Zahid Hamidi previously indicated the state poll could occur within the next two to ten months, highlighting challenges for Melaka Umno leaders due to limited preparation time. In the 2021 Melaka election, Barisan Nasional won 21 of 28 contested seats. The current state legislative assembly’s five-year term ends in December 2026.

**Upcoming DAP congress just a PR exercise, says Urimai's Ramasamy**
P Ramasamy, former DAP deputy chairman and current chair of Urimai, dismissed the upcoming DAP congress on July 12, 2026, as a 'public relations exercise' with no real impact on government policy. He questioned the purpose of the congress, arguing that even if DAP leaders resign from government positions following the vote, the party would still remain in coalition with the government. According to Ramasamy, the government is aware that DAP will not withdraw support, rendering the congress ineffective as a tool for pressuring reforms. The congress, announced by DAP secretary-general Loke Siew Fook, is framed as an internal 'referendum' following the party's poor performance in the Sabah polls. Delegates will vote on whether party leaders should resign from ministerial, deputy ministerial, state executive, local council, and GLC roles. However, Loke emphasized that regardless of the outcome, DAP MPs will continue supporting the government until the next general election and will not participate in any 'backdoor government' attempts. The article was published on February 20, 2026, by Free Malaysia Today.

**DAP to hold July 12 congress on whether its leaders should quit their government, GLC posts**
The Democratic Action Party (DAP) plans to hold a special congress on July 12, 2026, to decide whether its leaders should resign from all government positions—including ministerial, deputy ministerial, state executive council, local council, and government-linked company roles—while continuing to support the unity government led by Prime Minister Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim. According to a report in Malay Mail, citing secretary-general Anthony Loke, over 4,000 central delegates will participate in what Loke described as an internal 'referendum'. This marks the first time such a major political decision will be referred to the party’s highest decision-making body rather than being decided solely by the Central Executive Committee. Loke emphasized that DAP’s 40 Members of Parliament will continue supporting Anwar’s government until the next general election and will not participate in any attempt to form a 'backdoor government'. He stated that collective responsibility is essential and warned against 'governing while opposing from within'. The decision follows DAP’s failure to win any of the eight seats it contested in the November 2025 Sabah state election, losing all the constituencies it previously held in the state assembly.

Source:[Malay Mail](https://www.malaymail.com/news/malaysia/2026/02/20/dap-to-hold-july-12-congress-on-whether-its-leaders-should-quit-their-government-glc-posts/209703)

**DAP to decide on July 12 if its leaders should resign from govt posts, says Loke**
The Democratic Action Party (DAP) will hold a special congress on July 12, 2026, to decide whether its leaders should resign from all government posts—including ministerial, deputy ministerial, state executive councillor, local council, and government-linked company roles—while continuing to support the unity government in Parliament, according to DAP secretary-general Anthony Loke. More than 4,000 central delegates are expected to vote, marking the first time such a major political decision is referred to the party’s highest decision-making body rather than being determined solely by the Central Executive Committee (CEC). The move follows a significant setback in the November 2025 Sabah state election, prompting a six-month reform period and a reassessment of DAP’s role in the ruling coalition. Loke described the congress as an internal 'referendum', emphasizing that even if delegates vote for resignation, DAP’s 40 MPs will continue to support Prime Minister Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim’s unity government until the next general election. DAP currently holds the most government positions among coalition parties: five ministerial posts, seven deputy ministerial roles, four senatorships, one chief ministership, one state ministership, 21 state executive councillor positions, and hundreds of local and village appointments. Originally scheduled for September, the congress was moved forward to July 12. Loke stressed that the party cannot 'have it both ways'—if it stays in government, it must act as a unified body and speak with one voice. He clarified that the decision is not a threat to the Prime Minister, nor does it signal intent to form a 'backdoor government'. The congress will also allow open debate on broader strategic questions, including whether to remain in Pakatan Harapan, contest independently, or revert to using the party’s Rocket symbol. Once a decision is made, all members must abide by it without ambiguity, Loke stated. The decision will shape DAP’s direction for the next 12 to 18 months.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 19, 2026 09:13 PM
Source:[thestar.com.my](https://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2026/02/19/dap-to-decide-on-july-12-if-its-leaders-should-resign-from-govt-posts-says-loke)

**DAP congress in July to review role in government**
The Democratic Action Party (DAP) will hold a special congress on July 12, 2026, in Petaling Jaya to determine whether its leaders should resign from their roles in the unity government while continuing to support it in Parliament. According to DAP secretary-general Loke Siew Fook, 4,000 delegates will vote on whether party leaders should step down as ministers, deputy ministers, state executive councillors, local councillors, and GLC representatives. This marks the first time the party has entrusted such a major political decision to a congress rather than the central executive committee (CEC), making it an internal 'referendum'. Loke emphasized that regardless of the outcome, DAP MPs will continue supporting the government until the next general election and will not withdraw support or participate in forming a 'backdoor government'. He clarified that the move is not a threat to Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim but a review of DAP’s role in government, noting that some leaders are still adjusting to the pressures of being in power after years in opposition. The congress is described as the highest decision-making body, with Loke stating the process aims to be more institutionalized and democratic. This decision follows DAP and Pakatan Harapan’s defeat in the Sabah state election on December 2, 2025, where DAP lost all eight contested seats. Loke stated the party would work closely with Anwar to accelerate reforms over the next six months. However, political analysts warn that without concrete actions, the push for reform could be perceived as 'political sugar coating'.

Publish date: February 19, 2026 03:07 PM
Source:[Free Malaysia Today](https://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2026/02/19/dap-congress-in-july-to-review-role-in-government)

**Continuous moderate rainfall forecast to impact Sabah until tomorrow**
According to Dr Mohd Hisham Mohd Anip, Chief Director of Malaysia Meteorological Department (MetMalaysia), continuous moderate rainfall is expected to affect Sabah until tomorrow, February 20, 2026. The affected areas include the West Coast (Ranau and Kota Belud), Sandakan (Telupid, Beluran, and Sandakan), and Kudat. The public is advised to access up-to-date weather information via the official MetMalaysia website, the myCuaca app, or the department’s social media platforms. Additionally, inquiries can be made by contacting MetMalaysia’s hotline at 1-300-22-1638. This warning follows a prior alert about severe continuous rainfall in Sabah and Sarawak. The announcement was issued at 2:00 PM on February 19, 2026, by Sinar Harian.

**Sabah by-elections: Voting more proceeds without disruption since this morning**
The Kinabatangan parliamentary and Lamag state by-elections in Sabah proceeded without disruption across all 36 polling centres on Saturday, January 24, 2026, following the death of incumbent Datuk Seri Bung Moktar Radin on December 5, 2025. Despite the short interval—just two months after the 2025 Sabah state election—voters, including those from remote areas like Kampung Bilit Seberang and Kampung Kuamut, turned up calmly and efficiently, with some travelling up to six hours by river to reach polling stations. To streamline the process, voters had their pinky fingers inked instead of the index finger. The atmosphere remained orderly, with election staff performing duties smoothly and small traders benefiting from steady turnout, selling pastries and beverages near polling centres. One seller, Khairul, noted the morning crowd resembled that of the November 2025 election. Official results are expected to be announced tonight at Dewan Sri Lamag.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 24, 2026 05:18 AM
Source:[The Star ](https://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2026/01/24/sabah-by-elections-voting-more-proceeds-without-disruption-since-this-morning)

**Polling opens at 36 centres as Kinabatangan and Lamag voters head to the ballot box**
Polling centres for the Kinabatangan parliamentary and Lamag state by-elections opened simultaneously at 7:30 a.m. on January 24, 2026, across 36 locations with 117 polling streams in Kinabatangan, Sabah. A total of 48,282 voters participated in the election to choose a new Member of Parliament for Kinabatangan and a new State Assemblyman for Lamag. Two centres closed at noon, while the remaining 34 closed in stages from 1 p.m. to 5:30 p.m. according to scheduled voting times. Vote counting will take place at Dewan Sri Lamag, with official results expected by 10 p.m. The Election Commission reported that 1,106 EC staff and 926 police officers were involved in securing the process. Of the 176 police personnel, 93% had already voted as early voters. The Kinabatangan seat is contested by Mohd Kurniawan Naim Moktar (Barisan Nasional), Datuk Saddi Abdul Rahman (Warisan), and Goldam Hamid (Independent). The Lamag seat features a contest between Mohd Ismail Ayob (BN) and Mazliwati Abdul Malek (Warisan). All five candidates cast their votes today at designated schools: Mohd Kurniawan at SK Bilit, Saddi at SK Batu Puteh, Goldam at SK Pekan Tongod, Mohd Ismail at SK Bukit Garam II, and Mazliwati at SK Buang Sayang. The incumbent, Datuk Seri Bung Moktar Radin, died on December 5, 2025, at age 66. He previously won the Kinabatangan seat in the 15th General Election with a 4,330-vote majority and the Lamag seat in the November 29, 2025, Sabah state election with a 153-vote majority.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 24, 2026 12:14 AM
Source:[Malay Mail](https://www.malaymail.com/news/malaysia/2026/01/24/polling-opens-at-36-centres-as-kinabatangan-and-lamag-voters-head-to-the-ballot-box/206552)

**Kinabatangan, Lamag by-election results expected by 10pm on Saturday, says EC**
The Election Commission (EC) of Sabah announced that results for the Kinabatangan parliamentary and Lamag state by-elections are expected by 10 pm on Saturday, January 24, 2026. EC Chairman Datuk Seri Ramlan Harun cited geographical challenges, including remote polling centres accessible only by helicopter or boat, as key factors influencing the timeline. To ensure all ballot boxes reach the official tallying centre at Dewan Sri Lamag within the stipulated timeframe, the EC has implemented proactive measures, including earlier closure of polling centres in interior areas—moved from 3 pm to 2 pm—to prevent delays due to worsening weather, a problem experienced during the previous Sabah state election. Eight polling centres will use helicopter transport, and one (Sekolah Kebangsaan Tundun Bohangin) will rely on boat services. The EC has also enhanced technical preparedness with Starlink connectivity and backup power supplies. Voter turnout is targeted at over 65%. As of January 20, 2026, at 9 am, 20.1% of 196 police personnel had voted in the Kinabatangan by-election, and 23.4% in the Lamag by-election. No election offences were reported as of yesterday, though one complaint was received this morning, pending official confirmation. The Kinabatangan by-election features a three-cornered contest: Mohd Kurniawan Naim Moktar (Barisan Nasional), Datuk Saddi Abdul Rahman (Warisan), and Goldam Hamid (Independent). The Lamag seat has a straight contest between Mohd Ismail Ayob (BN) and Mazliwati Abdul Malek (Warisan). The by-elections were triggered by the death of incumbent Datuk Seri Bung Moktar Radin on December 5, 2025. Kinabatangan has 48,722 registered voters across three state seats (Sukau, Lamag, Kuamut), and Lamag has 13,899 electors. A total of 36 ordinary polling centres with 117 polling streams will be used.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 20, 2026 05:14 AM
Source:[Malay Mail](https://www.malaymail.com/news/malaysia/2026/01/20/kinabatangan-lamag-by-election-results-expected-by-10pm-on-saturday-says-ec/206070)

**Nominations open for Kinabatangan, Lamag by-elections**
The nomination centre for the Kinabatangan parliamentary and Lamag state by-elections opened at 9:00 AM on Saturday, January 10, 2026, at Dewan Sri Lamag. Candidates had one hour to submit nomination papers, after which the returning officer, Eddy Syaizul Rizam Abdullah, announced the list of eligible contenders at 10:00 AM. The by-elections were triggered by the death of incumbent Datuk Seri Bung Moktar Radin on December 5, 2025, at age 66. Bung Moktar had won the Kinabatangan seat in the 15th General Election with a 4,330-vote majority over Warisan's Mazliwati Abdul Malek and retained the Lamag state seat in the 17th Sabah State Election on November 29, 2025, with a 153-vote margin in a six-cornered contest. Polling is scheduled for January 24, 2026, with early voting on January 20. A total of 48,722 registered voters—comprising 48,526 ordinary voters and 196 police personnel and their spouses—will vote across 36 polling centres with 117 voting streams and one early voting centre.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 10, 2026 01:19 AM
Source:[The Star ](https://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2026/01/10/nominations-open-for-kinabatangan-lamag-by-elections)

**Curtain opens for Kinabatangan, Lamag polls tomorrow**
The Kinabatangan parliamentary and Lamag state by-elections in Sabah, Malaysia, will proceed with the nomination process on January 10, 2026, at Sri Lamag Hall. Prospective candidates must submit nomination forms between 9:00 AM and 10:00 AM at the Candidate Nomination Centre (PPC). The Election Commission (EC) will declare eligible candidates after the process concludes. Barisan Nasional has nominated Mohd Naim Kurniawan, son of the late Datuk Seri Bung Moktar Radin and Umno Youth chief, for Kinabatangan, and Mohd Ismail Ayob (Miha), a former Independent candidate in the 17th Sabah state election, for Lamag. Parti Warisan has named former Sukau assemblyman Datuk Saddi Abdul Rahman for Kinabatangan and party supreme council member Mazliwati Abdul Malek for Lamag. These by-elections follow the death of incumbent Bung Moktar on December 5, 2025. A 14-day campaign period will run from the candidate declaration until 11:59 PM on January 23, 2026. There are 48,722 registered voters, including 48,526 regular voters and 196 early voters (police and spouses). Polling will be conducted at 36 regular polling centres with 117 channels and one early polling centre with one channel. Polling day is set for January 24, with early voting on January 20. The Malaysian Meteorological Department (MetMalaysia) forecasts rainy weather in Kinabatangan on nomination day. Sabah Police Commissioner Datuk Jauteh Dikun confirmed 926 officers have been deployed for security. Road closures are scheduled: Jalan Dato Pengiran Galpam from Syariah Court to Simpang 3 towards Jalan Dato Malek Chua will be closed from 7:00 AM on nomination day and from 5:00 PM on polling day until vote counting concludes and the winner is announced.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 09, 2026 04:48 AM
Source:[The Star ](https://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2026/01/09/curtain-opens-for-kinabatangan-lamag-polls-tomorrow)

**Kinabatangan and Lamag by-elections seen as litmus test for Sabah's unity govt**
The Kinabatangan parliamentary and Lamag state by-elections in Sabah, scheduled for January 24, 2026, are seen as a critical test for the unity government's ability to function cohesively on the ground. Barisan Nasional candidate Mohd Naim Kurniawan Moktar, son of the late incumbent Bung Moktar Radin, emphasized that the contest would reveal whether coalition parties can unite, especially with Parti Warisan fielding experienced candidates—Datuk Saddi Abdul Rahman in Kinabatangan and Mazliwati Abdul Malek Chua in Lamag. Warisan's deputy president Datuk Darell Leiking stated the party respects Bung Moktar and aims to give voters a local alternative to represent their voices in the Madani government. Political analysts, including Associate Prof Dr Lee Kuok Tiung from Universiti Malaysia Sabah and senior lecturer Tony Paridi Bagang from Sabah UiTM, note Barisan's advantage due to emotional sympathy for Bung Moktar, traditional patronage, and strong personal appeal of Naim Kurniawan. Prof Lee warned that opposition campaigning against Bung Moktar could backfire, while stressing the need for Sabah-based leaders to lead the campaign. Although Warisan’s support base in Lamag was described as 'narrow and fragmented'—evidenced by Mohd Saifulah Lokman losing his deposit in the recent Lamag by-election—analysts believe Warisan could mount a strong challenge in Kinabatangan, where it secured a notable share of votes in GE15. However, both agree that voter sympathy for Bung Moktar’s legacy is likely to favor Barisan in both constituencies. The by-elections were triggered by Bung Moktar’s death on December 5, 2025, and nominations are set for January 10, 2026.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 06, 2026 05:26 AM
Source:[The Star ](https://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2026/01/06/kinabatangan-and-lamag-by-elections-seen-as-litmus-test-for-sabah039s-unity-govt)

**EC sets Jan 24 polling day for Kinabatangan, Lamag by-elections**
The Election Commission (EC) has set January 24, 2026, as the polling day for the dual by-elections in the Kinabatangan parliamentary seat and the Lamag state seat in Sabah, following the death of elected representative Datuk Bung Moktar Radin on December 5, 2025, due to lung and kidney complications. Nomination day is scheduled for January 10, 2026, and early voting will occur on January 20, four days prior to polling day. The official campaign period will last 14 days and is estimated to cost RM10 million, with 1,106 election personnel deployed. A total of 36 ordinary polling centres with 117 polling streams and one early voting centre will be used. Both the Nomination Centre and the Official Vote Tallying Centre will be located at Dewan Sri Lamag, Kinabatangan. The electoral roll includes 48,722 voters—48,526 ordinary voters and 196 police personnel—as of December 5, 2025. Postal voting applications, including for election workers, security personnel, media practitioners, and overseas voters, opened on December 16, 2025, and must be submitted online via the EC portal. Four election campaign enforcement teams, comprising police, local authorities, and candidates, will ensure orderly campaigning. The EC has invited government agencies, NGOs, and interested bodies to apply as election observers by December 31, 2025. Live streaming of selected polling stations will be provided, and the 'Jom Kita Undi' campaign will be intensified to boost voter turnout. Voters are urged to verify their voting details starting January 5, 2026, through the MySPR Semak portal, mobile app, or EC hotline.

**EC sets Jan 24 for twin Kinabatangan, Lamag by-elections**
The Election Commission (EC) has announced that twin by-elections for the parliamentary constituencies of P187 Kinabatangan and N58 Lamag in Sabah will be held on January 24, 2026. The nominations date has been set for January 10, 2026, and early voting will take place on January 20, 2026. The updated electoral roll includes 48,722 registered voters. The announcement was made by EC chairperson Ramlan Harun during a press conference following a meeting in Putrajaya.
